author: By Emma Goldberg and Lora Kelley
title: Companies Are More Vocal Than Ever on Social Issues. Not on Abortion.
description: The corporate response to the Supreme Court’s Friday decision was more muted, and the companies that did speak out mostly talked about their health care policies.
content: Companies had more than a month to formulate a response to the end of federal abortion rights in the United States, if they didn’t weigh in immediately after a draft opinion was leaked in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: With New Threats Looming, Canada Commits Billions to Air Defense
description: But it is unclear that giving new capabilities to Norad will be effective against new, superfast missiles.
content: Spending on military programs often leads to years of heated political debate and little action in Canada. But the announcement this week that Canada will spend nearly 5 billion Canadian dollars over the next six years on upgrading Norad’s defense systems passed with barely a ripple of controversy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar Junta Sends Aung San Suu Kyi to Solitary Confinement
description: The United Nations and human rights advocates criticized the transfer from house arrest, and urged the regime to free her and all other political prisoners.
content: Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, has been transferred from house arrest to prison and is being held in solitary confinement, according to a spokesman for the military junta that seized power last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Olympics Snub Women’s Nordic Combined and Put the Sport on Notice
description: The International Olympic Committee said not enough countries are participating in the women’s competitions to include them. The men’s event may be the next to go.
content: The International Olympic Committee decided Friday not to add a women’s Nordic combined event to the 2026 Winter Games in Milan and Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy, a devastating setback for dozens of women who have dedicated their lives to the event in recent years and a potentially fatal blow to one of the original Winter Olympic competitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyleigh McPeek
title: This Is How We Talk About Ending Things
description: First we agree to stop seeing each other. Then we pretend we never had that conversation.
content: We decided to go to 7-11 to restock our caffeine supplies. He wanted his favorite brand of iced coffee; I wanted some of those Yerba Mate energy drinks. These caffeine treks had become a new sort of love language for us, my growing feelings manifesting through the memorization of his coffee order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Lai
title: Members of Congress voice mixed opinions on the Roe ruling.
description: Lawmakers trickled into the Capitol on Friday to tightened security and the news of Roe v. Wade being overturned.
content: As members of Congress flooded into the Capitol on Friday morning for a packed legislative day before a recess, news of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade reverberated through the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael C. Bender
title: The Man Most Responsible for Ending Roe Worries That It Could Hurt His Party
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has privately told friends and advisers that a ruling overturning Roe v. Wade will be “bad for Republicans.”
content: The end of the landmark Roe v. Wade ruling was the culmination of decades of work by Republicans and social conservatives — one that came to pass only after a former Democrat from New York who had once supported abortion rights helped muscle through three Supreme Court justices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: These Homeowners Decided to Rent Again
description: Some homeowners looked at rising home prices and decided to get out while the going was still good. Now they’re renters again.
content: As a general rule, it’s a bad idea to try to time a market, and housing is no exception. But some homeowners who’ve been sitting on the sidelines watching their home values soar have decided that now is the time to cash out before a downward slide takes hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: The Simplest Salmon and Other Easy Recipes
description: A vegetable tofu curry, a tuna mayo rice bowl, a crispy-edged quesadilla: You don’t have to be great in the kitchen to get delicious results.
content: Earlier this year, one of our editors, Nikita Richardson, suggested that we do a package of recipes for true beginner cooks, a step-by-step program for people who can barely boil water. The recipes needed to be great, because not only do we want you to learn to cook, we also want you to love it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: ‘Buy Now, Pay Later’ Becomes a New Way to Pay for Guns
description: Credova, a little-known fintech company, is leading the way in offering installment plans to buyers of guns and hunting supplies.
content: A few years ago, as American consumers were being wooed with “buy now, pay later” loans that let them pay for online purchases — from makeup to Peloton bikes — in small increments, one start-up had an idea: Why not adapt the model to sell outdoor recreation gear, including guns?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung and Carly Olson
title: Where can the youngest U.S. children get vaccinated? Maybe not at your local pharmacy. Here’s why.
description: Age requirements vary among the larger pharmacy chains, and some won’t give the shots to children younger than 5.
content: U.S. children as young as 6 months are now eligible for coronavirus vaccines, and many parents are breathing a sigh of relief. But the pharmacy that offered easy access to immunization to you or an older child might not accommodate the under-5 group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeneen Interlandi and Kholood Eid
title: 12 Americans Die of an Overdose Every Hour. We Have the Knowledge to Prevent That.
description: Why haven’t we solved the addiction crisis?
content: For most of his life, Harris Marquesano struggled to live inside his own skin. He was a sweet boy — affectionate with his parents, protective of his little sister and devoted to his friends. But he had more energy than he knew what to do with, and he worried almost constantly. In preschool, when his teacher had to have surgery, he was so distressed by her absence that he tried to take over his classroom, presiding over each playgroup like a tiny, anxious general. By junior high, he was acting out in earnest. Some of Harris’s teachers suggested to his mother, Stephanie Marquesano, that he was just testing limits. But she knew it was more than that. “He was crawling out of his own skin half the time,” she said. “Running around and acting out was the only way for him to manage that feeling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Monkeypox and the Gay Community
description: Many monkeypox cases have been found in men who have sex with men.
content: This weekend marks the end of Pride month, as cities across the country host events to celebrate the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: You Deserve Better, No Matter What Your Boss Says (or Doesn’t)
description: From not working when you shouldn’t to needing your manager to show some common decency, it’s OK to stick up for yourself.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Documenta Was a Whole Vibe. Then a Scandal Killed the Buzz.
description: Accusations that an image was antisemitic broke the mood at a daring festival of experiments. This year’s Documenta deserves a closer look, our critic says.
content: KASSEL, Germany — No one knows just how big Documenta 15 is. The latest edition of the prestigious international art exhibition, which takes place every five years here, opened last Saturday and runs through mid-September. It resists all the usual metrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Paulo Dybala and the Problem With Italy
description: The travails of Dybala, whose contract with Juventus runs out this month, are emblematic of a soccer ecosystem that is often a world apart.
content: Paulo Dybala did not, particularly, look as if he were ready to say goodbye. As the lights at the Allianz Stadium in Turin, his home for the last seven years, flashed and flickered, and Tina Turner’s “The Best” began its crescendo, he started to cry. Not in the sense of a single, elegant tear rolling down the cheek. He sobbed. He racked. His chest heaved as he gulped for air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Juul Users Prepare to Say Goodbye to Their Vape of Choice
description: After a Food and Drug Administration ruling against the company, fans of the brand said they appreciated its simple design. “I definitely will miss the Juuls,” a leather worker in Detroit said.
content: After roughly 25 years of cigarette smoking, Tim Marchman wanted to quit. And yet he didn’t want to become what he calls “a vape guy,” the kind of person who spends hours in specialty shops choosing from dozens of electronic nicotine delivery devices, many of them quite elaborate. So he settled on what struck him as the simplest option, Juul, a brand that for a time was practically synonymous with vaping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Schechter
title: Meet the New Man Behind the National Park Service
description: The park service’s first Native American director, Charles F. Sams III, has plans to address overcrowding, improve accessibility and share the country’s untold stories.
content: Last December, Charles F. Sams III made history when he became the first Native American to be appointed director of the National Park Service. He had his work cut out for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Special Edition: Roe v. Wade Is Overturned
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of Friday.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: After Years of Acrimony, China and Australia Cautiously Reach Out
description: The arrival of a new government in Canberra has set the stage for ministerial talks and overtures for easing tensions. Plenty still divides the two nations.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Four years after Australia’s ties with China entered a downward spiral, with Australia emerging as an energetic counterweight to Beijing’s growing might, the two countries have begun to explore whether they can patch things up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Shawn Hubler, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: States Rush to Revamp Laws After Supreme Court’s Gun Ruling
description: After some restrictions on gun permits were deemed unconstitutional, legislators announced plans to craft new laws that honor the ruling while still creating limits.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: How Alton Mason Went from ‘Male Model of the Year’ to ‘Elvis’
description: Once known for doing back flips on the runway, the 24-year-old makes his acting debut playing Little Richard.
content: Name: Alton Mason
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jamelle Bouie
description: A conversation with New York Times Opinion columnist Jamelle Bouie.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jamelle Bouie. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Rhodes Scholar’s Starbucks Ambition and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Solomon
title: For the Most Complex Heroines in Animation, Look to Japan
description: The girls and women of anime tend to experience the conflicting emotions of real life. That’s because the auteurs try to create “an everyday, real person.”
content: At a time of widespread debate over the depiction of women in film, the top Japanese animators have long been creating heroines who are more layered and complex than many of their American counterparts. They have faults and weaknesses and tempers as well as strengths and talents. They’re not properties or franchises; they’re characters the filmmakers believe in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Pennsylvania’s race for governor takes on huge stakes for abortion rights.
description: If Doug Mastriano, the Republican nominee, beats his Democratic opponent, Josh Shapiro, he and the state’s G.O.P.-led legislature are all but certain to move to outlaw abortion.
content: Now that the Supreme Court has struck down Roe v. Wade, the most important election this year in America when it comes to abortion will be the contest for governor of Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol and Matt Stevens
title: F.B.I. Raids Orlando Museum and Removes Basquiat Paintings
description: All 25 works in the museum’s Jean-Michel Basquiat exhibition were seized by the F.B.I. An affidavit called into question their origin and their authenticity.
content: The Federal Bureau of Investigation raided the Orlando Museum of Art on Friday, taking all 25 works that had been part of an exhibition on the life and work of Jean-Michel Basquiat, the museum said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Conservatives Lose 2 Races in U.K., Adding to Pressure on Boris Johnson
description: The double defeat exposed the party’s vulnerabilities and was likely to revive talk of another no-confidence vote against the prime minister.
content: LONDON — Britain’s governing Conservative Party lost two strategically important parliamentary seats on Friday, prompting the resignation of a party chairman and raising fresh doubts about the future of the country’s scandal-scarred leader, Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Let the Record Show’ and ‘Hell of a Book’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: LET THE RECORD SHOW: A Political History of ACT UP New York, 1987-1993, by Sarah Schulman. (Picador, 752 pp., $22.) Schulman’s book, based on 17 years of interviews with nearly 200 members of the influential direct-action group committed to ending AIDS, “doesn’t seek to memorialize history but to ransack it,” the former Times critic Parul Sehgal wrote. “This is not reverent, definitive history. This is a tactician’s bible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Does Your Nose Help Pick Your Friends?
description: In a small study, researchers in an olfaction lab found that people who had an instant personal connection also had similarities in their body odors.
content: Human beings maintain the polite fiction that we’re not constantly smelling one another. Despite our efforts to the contrary, we all have our own odors, pleasant and less so, and if we are like other land mammals, our particular perfume might mean something to our fellow humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Najim Rahim, Cora Engelbrecht and Michael Crowley
title: Relief Efforts Intensify in Afghanistan After Devastating Earthquake
description: Aid has been streaming into the rugged regions hit by the quake on Wednesday. Hundreds were killed and many more are missing, with officials saying that they do not expect to find more survivors.
content: Relief efforts ramped up on Friday to aid victims of the deadly earthquake that struck an impoverished region of southeastern Afghanistan this week in a disaster that killed hundreds and devastated a country already teetering on economic collapse nearly a year after the Taliban seized power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: A Psychedelic Renaissance at the V.A.
description: Four Veterans Affairs clinicians, frustrated with existing treatments for addiction and PTSD, have turned to drugs the government still deems illegal.
content: The last known experiment at a Department of Veterans Affairs clinic with psychedelic-assisted therapy started in 1963. That was the year President John F. Kennedy was assassinated. “Surfin’ U.S.A.” topped the music charts, and American troops had not yet deployed to Vietnam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yoon Choi
title: How Droll: Story Collections Poke Fun at Human Contradiction
description: From Acapulco to Red Lobster, mushrooms to Middle Eastern Studies, new short fiction puts the tensions of modern life on full display.
content: Dream sequences. References to Heidegger and Red Lobster. Special appearances by a dog named Freud and a metaphysics-spouting dragon. A woman posing as a Surrealist painting of a woman looking in the mirror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Gloria Allen, Transgender Activist Who Ran a Charm School, Dies at 76
description: She overcame a life of intolerance and abuse to teach style, etiquette and life lessons to young transgender people who were at risk.
content: Gloria Allen, a transgender activist whose experiences running a charm school in Chicago for at-risk transgender youth inspired an acclaimed documentary film, “Mama Gloria” and play, “Charm,” died on June 13 at her home in Chicago. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick and Matthew Cullen
title: A New Status Quo
description: The Supreme Court declared that Americans have a broad right to arm themselves in public.
content: Two major developments in Washington yesterday upended the terrain of the American gun debate. The first was a Supreme Court ruling striking down a New York State law that restricted people’s ability to carry guns in public. The second was the Senate passage of a bipartisan bill that would become the most significant change to federal gun safety laws in nearly three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Dobbs, Named in Abortion Case Ending Roe, Had Little to Do With It
description: His name was affixed to the historic lawsuit after he became Mississippi’s chief health officer in 2018.
content: Dr. Thomas E. Dobbs III, the man whose name on Friday became synonymous with the Supreme Court decision to let states ban abortions, had almost nothing to do with the landmark case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Hot Economies and High Prices
description: An overview of the changes in inflation analysis.
content: It is a truth universally acknowledged — well, anyway, a truth acknowledged by everyone I know who thinks about the subject — that a hot economy leads to higher wages and prices. When demand for labor is strong, workers can and do demand wage hikes; when demand for goods and services is strong, businesses have “pricing power,” or the ability to raise prices without losing customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: How Does Temperature Affect Wine?
description: In hot weather, it’s important to think about the weight and serving temperature of a wine, rather than its color.
content: Some people imagine the best wines in hot weather are exclusively whites and rosés. But I have never subscribed to this thinking. I still want to drink reds with plenty of the foods that might end up on a grill at any sort of summer gathering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: On Broadway, One Show Decides to Keep Masks. No, It’s Not ‘Phantom.’
description: “American Buffalo,” at Circle in the Square, is sticking with masking till it closes, July 10, citing the “proximity of the audience to the actors” and “the staging in the round.”
content: Three days after the Broadway League announced that all 41 theaters would make masks optional starting July 1, one of those theaters has decided to stick with mandatory face coverings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg, Lora Kelley and Emily Flitter
title: Here are the companies that will cover travel expenses for employee abortions.
description: A handful of companies have committed to helping their employees access abortion services.
content: After the Supreme Court’s ruling ending federal abortion rights on Friday, several companies released statements reaffirming their commitment to helping employees access health care services they may not be able to obtain in their state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Marc Santora and Michael Levenson
title: Ukraine Retreats From Embattled City, as Russia Grinds On
description: With the withdrawal from Sievierodonetsk, the fighting shifts to neighboring Lysychansk, the last city in the Luhansk region still under Ukrainian control.
content: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — After weeks of bloody street fighting and months of withering artillery fire, Ukrainian forces will withdraw from Sievierodonetsk, a city that President Volodymyr Zelensky once said would determine the “fate” of the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fresh Fed financial disclosures omit the officials who ignited ethics scandal.
description: The Dallas and Boston regional Fed presidents whose 2020 trades caused an uproar resigned late in 2021. Their transactions from last year were excluded from a new wave of disclosures.
content: The Federal Reserve did not disclose updated financial information for two former regional bank presidents whose trading ignited a scandal at the central bank, even though they held important monetary policy roles for most of 2021 — the year covered by a fresh set of disclosures released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Gevisser
title: From Florida to Poland, We Must March for the Right to Exist
description: The boundary between freedom and oppression is thin.
content: Last Saturday, toward the end of the Riga-Kyiv Pride March for Freedom in Latvia, I saw a burly man in a unicorn head lean out of a second-floor window and wave grandly at the parade below. His yellow and blue shirt had “Kyiv” emblazoned across it. March participants had been leading the 5,000-strong crowd in the chant “Make love, not war,” artfully linking the right to love, everywhere, with the right to self-determination and peace in Ukraine. In response to the queer Minotaur in Ukraine’s colors, the marchers erupted into cries of “Slava Ukraini,” or “Glory to Ukraine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda M. Fairbanks
title: Truck Beach Was For Locals. Then the Oceanfront Homes Arrived.
description: In the Hamptons, a longstanding battle over a sliver of beach returns to court.
content: For as long as Nathaniel Miller can remember, he has spent every summer at a beach in Napeague, a once-remote strip of marsh, pine forest and dunes sandwiched between Amagansett and Montauk in the Hamptons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
title: Murder of 2 Priests Hands Mexican Leaders a New Critic: the Catholic Church
description: The government has failed for years to quell rising violence and the resulting public outcry, but the church’s voice cannot easily be dismissed.
content: MEXICO CITY — The murder of two Jesuit priests inside a church in Mexico this week stunned a country where frustration had been building for years over the government’s failure to stem a deluge of killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: San Francisco School Board Reverses Vote on Mural Removal
description: The historical painting of George Washington had been on view at a city high school since the 1930s. But a recent push to remove it set off a nationwide debate.
content: A school board’s decision in 2019 to remove a mural of George Washington that includes depictions of enslaved Black people and Native Americans set off a national debate about how American historical figures should be represented in educational settings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Politico’s Roe v. Wade scoop becomes law.
description: In May, Politico’s reporters published a draft opinion outlining the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. Today, the high court made it official.
content: The Supreme Court made huge headlines on Friday with its decision to end the constitutional right to abortion. But the decision was also unusual because it was already known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine and Bobby Doherty
title: 6 Cool Ice Pops to Make With Your Kids
description: It’s summer. Go wild.
content: On the hottest days of summer, there’s nothing better than a nice, cold ice pop — in theory, anyway. In reality, they can be a little meh, more like a stick of barely-flavored ice that immediately melts into a watery mess all over your hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Cultivate a Green Thumb
description: If you are known to turn a lush house plant into a rotting carcass, here are a few expert tips for making greenery thrive.
content: Once a year, I get inspired to try — yet again — to fill my home with beautiful house plants. I wander the aisles in my local nursery, pick out a few plants that look nice, bring them home and begin the process of slowly killing them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Buck Ellison’s Great White Society
description: From the driving range to the dude ranch, an artist stages intimate, alluring portraits of U.S. hegemony from within its walls.
content: Their beery, blueblood inhibition hangs in the periwinkle dusk. The photograph shows the two DeVos brothers, scions of the Amway multilevel marketing empire, finishing a game of golf with their dad. Two men crouch over a short putt. One nurses a can of low-cal Michelob Ultra. The third stands behind them, his stance strong, his back turned to the camera and to us, draining his bladder in a stream as straight as a titanium shaft. They seem firm and composed, in the flower of youth. And the fourth figure, the caddy saddled with the golf bag in the Everglades heat — who is he? He’s everyone else. He wants to be them, and maybe, if he tugs hard enough on his bootstraps, he will be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Does Keeping Jurors Unbiased Mean Keeping Everyone Else Quiet?
description: A journalist’s comments prompt the delay of a high-profile criminal trial, and everyone gets a reminder in how careful they need to be in discussing ongoing cases.
content: When Brittany Higgins, a former government staff member, came forward with her allegations of rape, which she said took place inside Australia’s Parliament building, the entire country was transfixed. Her claim that she had been assaulted by a colleague in the defense minister’s office while she was sleeping after a night of drinking prompted protests across Australia by women demanding changes in a male-dominated political culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Recruiting Trail Puts Basketball’s Changes on Display
description: Young prospects in men’s basketball have numerous ways to impress college coaches (and options to bypass them). But the way coaches are looking for new talent has changed, too.
content: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J. — Three days after traveling from his family’s vacation home in Porto Heli, Greece, Symeon Efstathiou found himself in a basketball gym at a remote boarding school tucked away in the northwest corner of New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Daily Harvest Recalls Lentil and Leek Crumbles After Consumers Fall Ill
description: With nearly 500 reports of sickness, and viral posts from influencers, the company and experts are now trying to figure out what happened.
content: The vegan food delivery service Daily Harvest recalled a lentil-based product after customers claimed on social media that they’d become severely sick after eating it. The company said that it had received approximately 470 reports of illness or adverse reactions, including gastrointestinal issues and potential liver damage, according to a press release issued Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: New York City Rent Increase: What You Need to Know
description: The increase will be the highest in nearly a decade.
content: New Yorkers who live in rent-stabilized apartments will soon pay higher rents — 3.25 percent more on one-year leases and 5 percent more on two-year leases — the sharpest increase in nearly a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Mike Ives
title: ‘I’ve Never Seen a Flood Like This’: Bangladesh Reels From Heavy Rains
description: South Asia is used to downpours, and occasional floods, during monsoon season. But this year’s flooding has been extreme, especially in Bangladesh.
content: PEKERKHAL, Bangladesh — Rohima Begum was cooking breakfast last week when the floodwaters flowed into her tin-and-bamboo home and began racing across the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazila Fathi
title: Haleh Afshar, Who Fought for Rights of Muslim Women, Dies at 77
description: An Iranian-born British scholar and self-described “Muslim feminist,” she joined the House of Lords and advised the British government on women’s issues.
content: Haleh Afshar, known as Lady Afshar, a prominent Iranian-British professor who dedicated her career in government and scholarship to promoting the rights of Muslim women, died on May 12 at her home in Heslington, England. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Title IX Promised Gender Equity. But Who Enforced It? Parents.
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 24, 2022.
content: “I was never a bra-burning feminist. But I was able to show my daughter that she can stand up for herself and not be treated as someone lesser or not equal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: What did Planned Parenthood v. Casey say?
description: In Planned Parenthood v. Casey in 1992, the Supreme Court affirmed what it called the central holding of Roe v. Wade: that states may not prohibit abortions before fetal viability, the point when a fetus could survive outside the womb, which is now about 23 weeks.
content: In Planned Parenthood v. Casey in 1992, the Supreme Court affirmed what it called the central holding of Roe v. Wade: that states may not prohibit abortions before fetal viability, the point when a fetus could survive outside the womb, which is now about 23 weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: ‘The Biggest Uncertainty Is Us’
description: Katharine Hayhoe, a climate scientist, says sustainable choices must become the easiest, most affordable ones.
content: I wanted to speak with Katharine Hayhoe about us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Confronts a ‘New World’ of Inflation
description: Central banks had a longstanding playbook for how inflation worked. In the postpandemic era, all bets are off.
content: Federal Reserve officials are questioning whether their longstanding assumptions about inflation still apply as price gains remain stubbornly and surprisingly rapid — a bout of economic soul-searching that could have big implications for the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaly Soto
title: World leaders react to Roe ruling.
description: Several European leaders criticized the Supreme Court’s decision, which goes against a global trend, while the Vatican welcomed it.
content: It applies to a single country, but the U.S. Supreme Court ruling scrapping the constitutional right to abortion reverberated globally, drawing a wave of responses from world leaders, some of them heated — “horrific,” “a huge setback” — as denunciation outweighed praise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: June 24, 2022: The Day Chief Justice Roberts Lost His Court
description: Outflanked by five impatient and ambitious justices to his right, the chief justice has become powerless to pursue his incremental approach.
content: WASHINGTON — In the most important case of his 17-year tenure, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. found himself entirely alone.

author: By Jeff Sommer

Any trepidation I had about it not measuring up vanished with the opening sentences: “Max liked to throw parties. The call would go out to the girls from the bar, the Harlem students who never went to Brooklyn except for her, and the confab of ladies we called les grandes dames, who lived in several apartments in a single building in Little Italy and spent their days making jam for each other and sending harassing letters to the editors of The Village Voice.”

The court said states could not ban abortions before fetal viability, the point at which the fetus can survive outside the womb. That was around 28 weeks at the time; because of improvements in medical technology, it is around 23 weeks now.

content: Even if we knew it was coming, the shock reverberates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: DeSantis has already moved to restrict abortions in Florida.
description: The state was once a refuge for the procedure in the Southeast.
content: Florida, the nation’s third-most populous state, also has the third-highest abortion rate, after New York and Illinois. Friday’s Supreme Court ruling and recent actions by Republican state leaders are expected to soon change that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: In Flint, a Pull to Clearer Waters Down South
description: The photographer LaToya Ruby Frazier traveled to Michigan in 2016 to document the ongoing crisis that sent one family back to the fresh springs of Mississippi.
content: Amid a financial crisis in 2014, Michigan’s then-governor Rick Snyder cut costs by switching the city of Flint’s water supply from Lake Huron (treated with corrosion controls at the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department) to the Flint River. Contaminated with fecal matter and other toxic waste, the river water was pumped through pipes that were leaching lead and sickened this predominantly Black city of about 100,000, nearly half of whom live in poverty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Erdos
title: These are the 15 Republican senators who voted for the bipartisan gun bill.
description: Fifteen Republican senators broke with their party to vote in favor of the bill, which passed 65 to 33.
content: The Senate passed a bipartisan measure aimed at gun safety, breaking a yearslong stalemate over federal legislation to address rampant violence. Fifteen Republican senators broke with their party to vote in favor of the bill, which passed 65 to 33. Only two of the Republicans who supported the bill are facing re-election this year, indicating how difficult it could be to advance similar compromises in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Campbell Robertson
title: Friday’s ruling prompts confusion and closures at abortion clinics.
description: Doctors and clinic owners were calling lawyers and looking for guidance from state attorneys general.
content: The Supreme Court’s decision overturning the constitutional right to abortion unleashed waves of confusion, panic and resignation for doctors and women across the country as they tried to understand a legal landscape that was changing by the hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: With Swag and Swagger, State Democrats Vie for Front of Presidential Primary Line
description: After Iowa’s disastrous 2020 caucuses, Democratic officials are weighing drastic changes to the 2024 calendar. States, angling for early attention, are waxing poetic. Behold, the New Jersey Turnpike!
content: WASHINGTON — High-ranking Democrats distributed gift bags and glossy pamphlets, waxing poetic about New Hampshire’s Manchester Airport and the New Jersey Turnpike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Watching ‘Queer as Folk’ but Craving ‘Heartstopper’
description: Major reboots and revivals are falling short in the writing as they try to diversify and expand their L.G.B.T.Q. worlds. It doesn’t have to be that way.
content: I’ve been watching gay television since Steven Carrington was a ’mo on “Dynasty.” I cried when a gay son died of AIDS in “An Early Frost,” rejoiced when Jack slipped Ethan the tongue on “Dawson’s Creek” and melted as Patrick married David on that other “Creek” — Schitt’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Ukraine’s foreign minister sees E.U. candidacy as a crucial step toward joining a ‘liberal empire.’
description: “History has been made,” he said of Ukraine’s being accepted as a candidate for E.U. membership.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — As the European Union summit began in Brussels on Thursday evening, an aide to Ukraine’s foreign minister tuned into the proceedings on a laptop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Baxter Black, Who Elevated Cowboy Poetry to Folk Art, Dies at 77
description: His wide-ranging work, including books, speeches and regular appearances on NPR, celebrated cowpokes, feed lots and life on the range.
content: Baxter Black, the country’s best-known cowboy poet, whose witty, big-hearted verse about cowpokes, feed lots and wide-open vistas elevated the tradition of Western doggerel to something of a folk art, died on June 10 at his home, a ranch outside Benson, Ariz. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: After Six-Decade Hiatus, Experimental Psychedelic Therapy Returns to the V.A.
description: A series of clinical trials using MDMA and psilocybin mushrooms represent a resurrection of promising research abandoned in the 1960s.
content: The Department of Veterans Affairs recently began offering psychedelic substances to patients as a part of clinical trials, a major step in the quest to determine the therapeutic potential of illegal drugs the federal government has long deemed dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Heat Waves Around the World Push People and Nations ‘To the Edge’
description: Large, simultaneous heat waves are growing more common. China, America, Europe and India have all been stricken recently, and scientists are starting to understand why certain far-flung places get hit at once.
content: Millions of Americans are once again in the grips of dangerous heat. Hot air blanketed Europe last weekend, causing parts of France and Spain to feel the way it usually does in July or August. High temperatures scorched northern and central China even as heavy rains caused flooding in the country’s south. Some places in India began experiencing extraordinary heat in March, though the start of the monsoon rains has brought some relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua M. Bernstein
title: Beer and Body Slams, as Craft Brewers and Wrestlers Get in the Ring
description: Small beer companies and independent wrestling leagues find that pairing their offerings attracts big crowds and big fun.
content: On a broiling Friday night in Brooklyn, beer fans gathered to try cold I.P.A.s from scores of breweries and blow off steam by screaming. In most contexts, raucous shouting is discouraged. But at Other Half Brewing’s Green City Championship beer festival, held this month at ZeroSpace, a sprawling events venue in Gowanus, crushing beer while cutting loose was precisely the point of the event’s entertainment: professional wrestling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Biden’s Gas Tax Holiday Wouldn’t Make Much Difference
description: The president’s proposal is mainly symbolic, to show he cares.
content: President Biden says he’s still committed to reducing U.S. carbon emissions to net zero in the near future. At the moment, though, his overriding priority is to ensure an ample supply of gasoline at reasonable prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: You Don’t Want to Wear a Mask? Do It for Hugh Jackman.
description: Beginning in July, Broadway will no longer require audiences to mask up. Actors and theater workers aren’t loving the idea.
content: Last month, in a much-celebrated moment of public disciplining during a talk back with the cast of “Company,” a woman in the audience who was told to please put her mask back on refused and then, mocking the directive, waved it in the air and placed it over her eyes. Up onstage, Patti LuPone was not having it and told her to get out. As if incubated in a lab manufacturing legend-resistant organisms — and unlike almost anyone else on the west side of Manhattan — this was a person immune to the ire of Patti LuPone. Yelling back defiantly, she proclaimed, “I pay your salary.” A member of the theater’s Covid safety staff proceeded to escort her out of the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Jan. 6 Hearings Have Been So Much Better Than I Expected
description: They might even change a few minds.
content: I felt a nauseating dread as the Jan. 6 hearings approached, fearing that all they would do is demonstrate Donald Trump’s impunity. That the former president attempted a coup has been obvious since his mob descended on the Capitol, if not before. With Trump, however, the question has never been whether he’s committed outrageous misdeeds, but whether those misdeeds can be made to matter. Over and over again, the answer to that question has been no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Williams
title: 3 Theaters, 3 Plays, One Cast, All at Once
description: The Crucible Theater in Sheffield, England, is celebrating its 50th anniversary with a mind-boggling logistical challenge that also honors a declining industry in the city.
content: SHEFFIELD, England — Visitors to Tudor Square in the center of this northern English city might spot some unusual figures there this week: a woman sprinting through in a neon boilersuit, or a tutu, or a man running with a box of scissors. And if they look like they’re in a hurry to get somewhere, that’s because they are. These are actors, and they have an entrance to make — on a different stage from the one they just left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard L. Hasen
title: No One Is Above the Law, and That Starts With Donald Trump
description: The prosecution of the former president is not only permissible but required for the sake of American democracy.
content: In a 2019 ruling requiring the former White House counsel Don McGahn to testify at a congressional hearing about former President Donald Trump’s alleged abuses of power, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson declared that “presidents are not kings.” If we take that admonition from our next Supreme Court justice seriously and look at the evidence amassed so far by the House select committee on the Jan. 6 attack, we can — and in fact must — conclude that the prosecution of Mr. Trump is not only permissible but required for the sake of American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: The Fall of Sievierodonetsk
description: Ukraine will withdraw its forces from the largely ruined eastern city.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: Party Animals?
description: What happens when some of our favorite creatures are left to their own devices.
content: TWO DOGSWritten and illustrated by Ian Falconer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Has Gun Law Ideas for New York
description: Noah says the state should propose new restrictions where “anyone can buy a gun if they want, but the gun stores are only open on the nights that the Knicks win.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Queen’s Protection
description: Sophia Maymudes and Margaret Seikel offer solvers a sizzling puzzle.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — One of the more exciting things I’ve witnessed among contributors to the New York Times Crossword is the rise of female constructors working together to bring new constructors and each other along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: After Many High School Reunions, Classmates Become Newlyweds
description: As members of Indianola High School’s class of 1992, Brenda Langstraat and Ve Bui saw each other every five years. Eventually, those reunions led to love.
content: Ve Bui loved high school so much, he thought it would go on forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalley Huang
title: Abortion funds raise millions in donations to help people seeking the procedure.
description: As of Friday afternoon, the National Network of Abortion Funds had received more than $3 million from about 33,000 new donations.
content: Abortion funds, the local organizations that provide financial and logistical support for people seeking abortions, have received millions of dollars in new funding after the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Ziegler
title: Roe’s Death Will Change American Democracy
description: The anti-abortion movement has won its decades-long effort to undo Roe. Now what?
content: The anti-abortion movement has long argued that reversing Roe v. Wade would strengthen American democracy. Roe, the argument goes, short-circuited a process of state-by-state debate and compromise, freezing the democratic process and imposing a single abortion solution on the nation. Undoing the constitutional right to abortion, then, is seen as a win for democracy — a first step in allowing each state to set its own policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Democrats turn to donors after the abortion decision, and Republicans follow suit — but with a different message.
description: Democrats’ fund-raising blasts filled email boxes and social media feeds as they aimed to capitalize on the fear and alarm that many left-leaning voters felt.
content: Democrats in some of the most competitive races for Senate and governor this year instantly appealed to donors on Friday after the Supreme Court overturned 50 years of precedent on abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks are scary, but not too scary. (Except the one about the demon on a rampage. That’s very scary.)
content: Because last month’s picks took a deep dive into depravity, this time I’m (mostly) sticking to low-gore, less-scary horror movies that won’t keep you up at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Before Riccardo Muti Leaves Chicago, a Verdi Farewell
description: “Un Ballo in Maschera” is the last in a series of Verdi operas led in concert by the Chicago Symphony’s music director, who departs after next season.
content: CHICAGO — Mortality, the fragility of life, permeates Verdi’s “Un Ballo in Maschera” from its lonely first measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Michael S. Schmidt and Alan Feuer
title: Panel Provides New Evidence That G.O.P. Members of Congress Sought Pardons
description: The House Jan. 6 committee played testimony from former Trump aides who said at least half a dozen Republicans had pre-emptively sought clemency.
content: At least half a dozen Republican members of Congress sought pre-emptive pardons from President Donald J. Trump as he fought to remain in office after his defeat in the 2020 election, witnesses have told the House Jan. 6 committee, the panel disclosed on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss, Alexandra Stevenson and Emily Schmall
title: In Russia’s War, China and India Emerge as Financiers
description: Their purchases of Russian crude are undermining the West’s efforts to isolate the Kremlin and upending the global oil markets.
content: As Russia tries to break the stranglehold of sanctions, China and India are emerging as Moscow’s pivotal financiers by purchasing large amounts of Russian crude, putting themselves in the middle of the messy war with Ukraine and a geopolitical standoff with the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Stocks have a rare positive week.
description: The S&P 500 had a weekly gain of about 6.5 percent, only its second positive week in the past twelve.
content: Stocks jumped on Friday in their best day in two years and posted a large gain for the week, a relatively rare development during a tumultuous time for Wall Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Ends Ban on Abortion Advertisement
description: The vote to scrap the law came on the same day that Roe v. Wade was overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court.
content: BERLIN — Lawmakers voted on Friday to end a Nazi-era ban on the advertisement of abortion services, a measure that had effectively criminalized doctors who provided information about the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: ‘Beba’ Review: Learning From Ancestors
description: An Afro-Latina filmmaker explores her identity and generational trauma growing up in New York City and attending a predominantly white college.
content: What’s most striking about the autobiographical documentary “Beba,” aside from the intimate lens and stunning cinematography, are its moments of vulnerability, which plunge the viewer into the Afro-Latina filmmaker’s familial and personal traumas, including heated arguments with her mother and her white friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: U.S.-Led Alliance Faces Frustration, and Pain of its Own, Over Russia Sanctions
description: Vladimir V. Putin is making gains in his war on Ukraine while the United States and its allies struggle with soaring energy prices and inflation.
content: WASHINGTON — Four months into the war in Ukraine, the countries aligned against Russia face growing economic pain even as sanctions and energy embargoes are showing little impact on Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign or his political standing at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: ‘At Their Breaking Point’: Tenants Fight to Stay in Their Homes
description: Since New York’s eviction moratorium ended in January, tenants and their landlords are returning to housing court.
content: Rocio Quero Yescas is 56 and walks with a cane, and she fears she will trip and fall because the floor tiles in her apartment keep peeling up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Christopher Clarey
title: Saudi Arabia, a Growing Force in Golf, Seeks to Host Women’s Tennis
description: The kingdom shook up the PGA Tour with the creation of the LIV Golf series. Now it is pushing to secure a WTA Tour event.
content: With the golf world already divided over Saudi Arabia’s emergence as a powerful force in the game, another major sport is contending with whether to do business with the kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Sleepy Baltic Rail Line Gets a Geopolitical Wakeup Call
description: Russia has accused Lithuania, a NATO member, of choking off the flow of goods to Kaliningrad, its enclave on the Baltic, as part of sanctions over the war in Ukraine. Lithuania says Russia is lying.
content: KYBARTAI, Lithuania — As war rages in Ukraine, fueling ever-growing tensions between NATO and Russia, a sleepy Baltic railway station with no passengers and few trains this week found itself at the center of a perilous new confrontation between East and West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Analysis: What the battle for Sievierodonetsk shows about the war.
description: Wars are not won by retreats. But it is also possible to win the battle and lose the war.
content: Wars are not won by retreats. But it is also possible to win the battle and lose the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Jan. 6 Has Surfaced America’s Disdain for Democracy
description: Jamelle Bouie explores what the Jan. 6 hearings reveal about America’s political project.
content: The Jan. 6 hearings have made it clear that Donald Trump led a concerted, monthslong effort to overturn a democratic election. The extensive interviews — over 1,000 — that the House select committee conducted prove that Trump was told there was no evidence of election fraud, but he pressed his anti-democratic case regardless. And it appears that the hearings may be making an impact on public opinion: An ABC News/Ipsos survey released Sunday found that 58 percent of respondents believe Trump should be charged with a crime for his role in the Jan. 6 attack, up from 52 percent in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Schoenfeld Walker and Allison McCann
title: How State Abortion Laws Are Changing
description: About half the states are expected to ban or further restrict access to abortion.
content: About half of states are expected to ban or further restrict access to abortion following the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, which for 50 years guaranteed the constitutional right to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Ukrainian insurgents kill a Kremlin-backed politician in occupied Kherson, part of a wave of attacks.
description: A growing guerrilla movement appears to have been fueled by public anger over worsening economic, security and humanitarian conditions.
content: Ukrainian guerrilla fighters claimed on Friday to have killed a Kremlin-backed politician in the Russian-controlled southern region of Kherson, the latest in a series of attacks aimed at destabilizing the occupation authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: As Russia Chokes Ukraine’s Grain Exports, Romania Tries to Fill In
description: With famine threatening millions, Europe is intent on finding alternatives to one of world’s biggest food exporters, whose landlocked crop is stranded by war.
content: Stopping at the edge of a vast field of barley on his farm in Prundu, 30 miles outside Romania’s capital city of Bucharest, Catalin Corbea pinched off a spiky flowered head from a stalk, rolled it between his hands, and then popped a seed in his mouth and bit down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vatican Releases Letters From Jews Pleading for Help During the Holocaust
description: Pope Francis has ordered files containing requests for assistance from people throughout Europe, many of them converts to Roman Catholicism, to be made available online.
content: ROME — Written between 1938 and 1944, and previously unreleased to the general public, the letters reveal desperation and fear. They reflect the humiliation, discrimination and confinement Jews were subjected to during a dark moment in European history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Here are past cases that have upheld or chipped away at Roe v. Wade.
description: The legal case over a law that makes most abortions illegal after 15 weeks of pregnancy is by no means the first to challenge or chip away at Roe v. Wade.
content: The Supreme Court’s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the case before the nation’s highest court on a restrictive Mississippi law, is the most consequential on women’s access to abortion since the court’s 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: The Sleep Debt Collector Is Here
description: Recent studies in humans and mice have shown that late nights and early mornings may cause long lasting damage to your brain.
content: The sleep debt collectors are coming. They want you to know that there is no such thing as forgiveness, only a shifting expectation of how and when you’re going to pay them back. You think of them as you lie in bed at night. How much will they ask for? Are you solvent? You fall asleep, then wake up in a cold sweat an hour later. You fall asleep, then wake up, drifting in and out of consciousness until morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Rise’ Review: To Be Giannis
description: The story of the real-life N.B.A. superstar Giannis Antetokounmpo is told with heartfelt charm in this endearing Disney+ biopic.
content: “Giannis: The Improbable Rise of an NBA MVP,” Mirin Fader’s biography of Giannis Antetokounmpo, portrays the Greek-born basketball superstar as a young man of sweet-natured innocence and irrepressible enthusiasm. Immigrating to the United States to play pro ball for the Milwaukee Bucks, where he was the 15th overall pick in the 2013 N.B.A. draft, he sees everything through eyes of guileless wonder: He’s dazzled by chocolate custard and hot dogs, by peanut butter bars and mixed-berry smoothies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Winning Her Heart Through His Way With Words
description: Alejandro Rojas and Jaclyn Belson met a year ago on the dating app Bumble. She was immediately drawn to his sense of humor. He was taken with her blue eyes.
content: While the photos Alejandro José Rojas had uploaded to the dating app Bumble caught Jaclyn Ariel Belson’s eye when she saw his profile in June 2021, it was the captions Mr. Rojas had written for the images that really stood out to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: How G.O.P. Support for Decriminalizing Abortion Faded Over Decades
description: Before the 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling, more Republicans than Democrats backed decriminalizing the procedure. But a political and religious coalition rose and took the party in a new direction.
content: Few can imagine it today, but on the eve of the Roe v. Wade ruling in 1973, more Republicans than Democrats supported decriminalizing abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Cheung, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rob Szypko, Lisa Tobin, M.J. Davis Lin, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: One Elite High School’s Struggle Over Admissions
description: A fierce debate about the criteria for enrolling students at Lowell, in California, has echoes of the soul-searching happening across the U.S. education system.
content: In recent months, meaningful questions have been asked about the tests that often sit at the heart of admissions to the top schools in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays, Michael Gold, Lola Fadulu and Hurubie Meko
title: Gov. Hochul Calls Decision Overturning Roe ‘Repulsive at Every Level’
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul declared New York a “safe harbor” for those seeking abortions as advocates and lawmakers in the state moved to respond to the Supreme Court ruling.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York responded on Friday morning to the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade by declaring her state a “safe harbor” for those seeking abortions and reaffirming her commitment to abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Marty
title: Mad About Roe? Here’s How to Help Women Now.
description: I wrote the “Handbook for a Post-Roe America.” It’s time to put it into practice.
content: In February 2021, I uprooted my husband, three children and two cats from our longtime home to move across the country to a house we had only seen on FaceTime, in a city we only knew from college football. I did this because I believe that everyone who supports abortion rights must do what they’re able to to keep abortion accessible for those who have the least resources to get one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Her Father Fled the Nazis. She’s the New U.S. Ambassador to Germany.
description: For Amy Gutmann, a respected democracy scholar, her role as President Biden’s envoy to Germany is not a job, “it’s a mission,” one both professional and personal.
content: FEUCHTWANGEN, Germany — After Amy Gutmann’s father fled the Nazis in 1934, he swore never to set foot in Germany again. For the rest of his life, he boycotted German goods and only spoke English to his daughter. Germany, he impressed on her when she was growing up, was “very bad.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: A Never-Ending Non-Conversation
description: Is a breakup a breakup if it’s barely acknowledged?
content: Kyleigh McPeek, the final finalist in our latest Modern Love college essay contest, has been dumped many times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Swallow Prior
title: I Prayed and Protested to End Roe. What Comes Next?
description: What the overturning of Roe v. Wade means to abortion opponents like me.
content: Roe v. Wade’s reversal has elicited cries of anger and despair from those who feel a sense of dread for the future of women and the future of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Ryan Mac
title: Meta clamps down on internal discussion of Roe v. Wade’s overturning.
description: Meta told its workers on Friday not to openly discuss the Supreme Court’s ruling eliminating the constitutional right to an abortion on wide-reaching communication channels inside the company, people with knowledge of the situation said.
content: Meta told its workers on Friday not to openly discuss the Supreme Court’s ruling eliminating the constitutional right to an abortion on wide-reaching communication channels inside the company, people with knowledge of the situation said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: In 6-to-3 Ruling, Supreme Court Ends Nearly 50 Years of Abortion Rights
description: The decision will lead to all but total bans on the procedure in about half of the states.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday overturned Roe v. Wade, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion after almost 50 years in a decision that will transform American life, reshape the nation’s politics and lead to all but total bans on the procedure in about half of the states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Following Recall, San Francisco School Board Reverses Course
description: The board voted this week to switch elite Lowell High School back to a merit-based admissions system.
content: San Francisco voters in February ousted three school board members in a landslide election that proponents hoped would reshape the city’s education policy and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Epiphany’ Review: A Holiday Party, but What Are We Celebrating?
description: In this heady Lincoln Center Theater production, Brian Watkins finds laughs and shivers in a pensive gathering of old friends.
content: I could describe Brian Watkins’s “Epiphany,” which opened Thursday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, as an existential dinner-party play. Or a satire of academics, armchair psychologists and the general intelligentsia, always trying to find a common language for our ways of living in the world. It could be called a critique of our modern society of self-interest. A statement on grief. Or a ghost story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Beyoncé’s Dance-Floor Salvation, and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Taylor Swift, the Mars Volta, Gorillaz featuring Thundercat and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times
